definition: to provide temporary quarters for, to rent lodgings to
examples: The refugees need to be lodged and fed.
hoped that they would lodge him for the winter

definition: to establish or settle in a place
examples: The troops lodged themselves in the town.

definition: to serve as a receptacle for : contain
examples: a sinus lodging the nerve and artery of the part

definition: to beat (a crop) flat to the ground
to bring to an intended or a fixed position (as by throwing or thrusting)
to deposit for safeguard or preservation
examples: agents collect the rent for the land, and lodge it in the bank

definition: to place or vest especially in a source, means, or agent
examples: a small family unit … with formal authority lodged in the father

definition: to lay (something, such as a complaint) before a proper authority : file
examples: the defendant then lodged an appeal

definition: to occupy a place temporarily : sleep
to have a residence : dwell, to be a lodger
examples: lodged with them for a year

definition: to come to a rest
examples: the bullet lodged in the wall

definition: to fall or lie down
examples: buckwheat … tends to lodge by late fall

definition: a rude shelter or abode
a house set apart for residence in a particular season (such as the hunting season)
a resort hotel : inn
a house on an estate originally for the use of a gamekeeper, caretaker, or porter
a shelter for an employee (such as a gatekeeper)
a den or lair especially of gregarious animals (such as beavers)
the meeting place of a branch of an organization and especially a fraternal organization
the body of members of such a branch
wigwam
a family of North American Indians
examples: The tribe consisted of about 200 lodges.

definition: Henry Cabot 1850–1924 American statesman and author
Henry Cabot 1902–1985 grandson of Henry Cabot Lodge American politician and diplomat
Sir Oliver Joseph 1851–1940 English physicist
Thomas 1558–1625 English poet and dramatist
